Issues.Title: When building winforms repo, global.json file is not fully respected
Issues.Body:
I discovered this on the 3.1 branch. I'm not sure if this is a winforms problem or an arcade problem, or how big of a problem it really is.

To reproduce:
1. Do a build.
1. Switcher to an older branch whose global.json specifies an older SDK version.
1. Do NOT clean the repo.
1. Do a build.

Expected: the precise SDK version specified in the global.json is used.
Actual: the `latestMajor` roll forward policy is applied and a newer SDK in the `.dotnet` folder of the repo is used.

An example build, where 3.1.100-preview1-014024 is the specified version in global.json and there is also a 3.1.100-preview2-999999 SDK in the .dotnet folder of the repo. Some parts elided with dots for brevity:

```cmd
C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms>set COREHOST_TRACE=1

C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms>build.cmd
Processing C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms\eng\..\global.json
..........
...........\msbuild.exe ............ C:\Users\AustinWise\.nuget\packages\microsoft.dotnet.arcade.sdk\1.0.0-beta.19461.7\tools\Build.proj
Tracing enabled @ Tue Oct 15 07:11:52 2019 GMT
--- Invoked hostfxr_resolve_sdk2 [commit hash: 7d57652f33493fa022125b7f63aad0d70c52d810]
Probing path [C:\Users\AustinWise\.nuget\packages\microsoft.dotnet.arcade.sdk\1.0.0-beta.19461.7\tools\global.json] for global.json
Probing path [C:\Users\AustinWise\.nuget\packages\microsoft.dotnet.arcade.sdk\1.0.0-beta.19461.7\global.json] for global.json
Probing path [C:\Users\AustinWise\.nuget\packages\microsoft.dotnet.arcade.sdk\global.json] for global.json
Probing path [C:\Users\AustinWise\.nuget\packages\global.json] for global.json
Probing path [C:\Users\AustinWise\.nuget\global.json] for global.json
Probing path [C:\Users\AustinWise\global.json] for global.json
Probing path [C:\Users\global.json] for global.json
Probing path [C:\global.json] for global.json
Terminating global.json search at [C:\]
Resolving SDKs with version = 'latest', rollForward = 'latestMajor', allowPrerelease = true
Searching for SDK versions in [C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms\.dotnet\sdk]
Version [3.1.100-preview1-014024] is a better match than [none]
Version [3.1.100-preview2-999999] is a better match than [3.1.100-preview1-014024]
SDK path resolved to [C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms\.dotnet\sdk\3.1.100-preview2-999999]
```

Note how the global.json is being search for in the Nuget packages folder.

It is possible to make the [SDK resolver respect the global.json file](https://github.com/dotnet/cli/blob/2f2f09d450887470a5f255f9496ae98b54994725/src/Microsoft.DotNet.MSBuildSdkResolver/MSBuildSdkResolver.cs#L293) by specifying the solution path:

```cmd
C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms>build.cmd /p:SolutionPath=%cd%\Winforms.sln
.............
...........\msbuild.exe ................. C:\Users\AustinWise\.nuget\packages\microsoft.dotnet.arcade.sdk\1.0.0-beta.19461.7\tools\Build.proj
Tracing enabled @ Tue Oct 15 07:27:15 2019 GMT
--- Invoked hostfxr_resolve_sdk2 [commit hash: 7d57652f33493fa022125b7f63aad0d70c52d810]
Probing path [C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms\global.json] for global.json
Found global.json [C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms\global.json]
--- Resolving SDK information from global.json [C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms\global.json]
Value 'sdk/rollForward' is missing or null in [C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms\global.json]
Value 'sdk/allowPrerelease' is missing or null in [C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms\global.json]
Resolving SDKs with version = '3.1.100-preview1-014024', rollForward = 'patch', allowPrerelease = true
Searching for SDK versions in [C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms\.dotnet\sdk]
Found requested SDK directory [C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms\.dotnet\sdk\3.1.100-preview1-014024]
SDK path resolved to [C:\externsrc\dotnet\winforms\.dotnet\sdk\3.1.100-preview1-014024]
```

I have some ideas about how this might be fixed:
* Change the winforms build scripts or arcade build scripts to pass the solution path. At least for the winforms repo, it appears the file specified for `SolutionPath` does not have to exist.
* Change the arcade SDK installation logic to delete the local .dotnet folder. Currently the scripts install the .NET SDK by extracting the correct version over any existing version. This leaves incorrect SDK versions in place.
* Document that one should always do a clean build when switching branches.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "When building winforms repo, global.json file is not fully respected" (#2085)

Issues.Title: add missing system drawing design editor associations
Issues.Body:
I believe we need to service these into 3.0. These associations will not exist at runtime meaning anyone with a property grid in their application trying to pull up an editor for any of these types or for that matter simply anyone trying to use `TypeDescriptor.GetEditor` for these types in an application will *not* get an editor.

This is a breaking change in compatibility against the classic framework. 

Further, it impacts our designer's ability to rely on the runtime.

## Proposed changes
- add editor entries corresponding types in System.Drawing to our ported editors

## Customer Impact
- Customers will be able to rely on common patterns to retrieve an editor for expected types. 

## Regression? 

- Yes 

## Risk
- minimal. This PR uses existing code paths and simply adds missing entries. 

## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->
- TBD, see https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/2089#issuecomment-542843786

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/2102)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "add missing system drawing design editor associations" (#2102)

Issues.Title: Implementing UIA supporting for Form control
Issues.Body:
## Issue description
- Form doesn't support UIA so it blocks #2074 because Narrator can't announce tooltip text if no controls on a form don't support UIA provider.

## Proposed changes
- Set SupportsUiaProviders property as true
- Use FormAccessibleObject as AccessibleObject instead default

**This allows customizing Form AccessibleObject how we want. 
For example, fix UIA navigation in the accessibility tree. It changes the focus order of Narrator. 
Form AccessibleObject works as before.**
<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Improved Bounds

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- No

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before
- There is space between Form borders and BoundingRectangle
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/66929718-2de1fd80-f03c-11e9-9fc0-3c0241ce27e8.png)

<!-- TODO -->

### After
- Bounds surround Form with more accuracy
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/66929554-e9566200-f03b-11e9-863c-6a5e1401fe07.png)

<!-- TODO -->


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual UI testing

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->
- Using Inspect tool
<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->


 

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->
- .NET Core Version: 3.1.0-preview1.19458.7
- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.18362.356]


<!-- Mention language, UI scaling, or anything else that might be relevant -->

Issues.Title: Mark deprecated controls as Non Browsable
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

**Problem description:**

The following types have been deprecated in .NET Framework:

* https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/DataGrid.cs (e.g. [deprecation warning](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.windows.forms.datagrid?view=netframework-4.8))
* https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/Menu.cs
* https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/MenuItem.cs
* https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/MainMenu.cs
* https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/ContextMenu.cs

However this fact was overlooked during the migration, and the types were brought into .NET Core 3.0.


**Expected behavior:**

The types are marked as obsolete and force consumers to use supported alternatives.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Mark deprecated controls as Non Browsable" (#2091)

Issues.Title: WIP [Accessibility]: Adding MonthCalendar control UI Automation providers to improve calendar control accessibility
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #1908
Fixes #1909
Fixes #1910
Fixes #1911 


## Proposed changes

- Adding MonthCalendar control UIA providers as accessibility implementation;
- Adding fragment navigation (Narrator caps navigation and announcing for each child);
- Adding Grid and Table providers for calendar body;
- Reworked accessibility implementation, hierarchy and overall accessibility providing patterns for control;
- Temporarily disabled legacy accessibility providers for control (will restore in next commits). 

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Customers will be able to navigate, listen to correct announcement and fully interact with the calendar control using desktop assistive technologies and apps.

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal (need to perform manual and automation verification to be sure that accessibility is correct for calendar control)

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

- Accessibility is provided only for the container (name) without navigation and no more info provided.

### After

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23213980/66873945-6b9a4400-efb2-11e9-903c-c951a9fb905e.png)


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual testing.
- Automation UI and accessibility test.
- Unit tests.

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->

- Need to perform tests including verification of accessible names, navigation and patterns provided correctly. Assistive technologies and accessibility client apps should work correctly with new accessibility.
 

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

.NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json):
 Version:   3.1.100-preview1-014044
 Commit:    dca04e7030

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows

Issues.Title: [loc][Query][winforms] Localizability of 0; "columnHeader1.Text"
Issues.Body:
Hi,
please help localization team to answer question from translator.
In case translator is not sure about context/meaning/localizability of string we raise a question.

Source:
ColumnHeader1

File Name:
System.Windows.Forms\tests\IntegrationTests\WinformsControlsTest\xlf\ListViewTest.xlf

==========================================
Query:
Is this entry translatable? Same for following strings:
ColumnHeader2 0; "columnHeader2.Text"
TableLayoutPanels 0; "$this.Text"
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue " [loc][Query][winforms] Localizability of 0; "columnHeader1.Text"" (#2087)

Issues.Title: Incorrect position of controls when layout is suspended
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.0 RTW
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No


**Problem description:**

When a controls layout is suspended, if anchors are specified, changing the location of that control will cause incorrect positions to occur when layout is resumed

**Actual behavior:**

![](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9663150/65137205-32999e80-da09-11e9-80f8-852861f4f392.gif)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Incorrect position of controls when layout is suspended" (#2084)

Issues.Title: translate winforms to use native calls on mac and linux?
Issues.Body:
right now winforms is the easiest to use but doesn't look native on other platforms.
I think if someone with the know how was willing to support other platforms natively it would be a better alternative for cross platform development then say xwt and eto.

I dislike the idea of anything related to wpf since its not native looking even on windows and is harder to use.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "translate winforms to use native calls on mac and linux?" (#2076)

Issues.Title: Cleanup NMTBHOTITEM
Issues.Body:
## Proposed Changes

Issues.Title: Porting System.Windows.Forms.Design.ListControlStringCollectionEditor
Issues.Body:
Fixes #1271 
Related issue: #1115
Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No

## Proposed changes

- Add System.Windows.Forms.Design.ListControlStringCollectionEditor class
- Add resources for DataSourceLocksItem
- Implement TypeForwardedTo method

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Changed collection editor for controls which use ListControlStringCollectionEditor (TextBox, ComboBox, ListBox, etc.) to compliance with .Net 4.8.

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- No

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->

Issues.Title: Cleanup `LVM`
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #


## Proposed changes

- WindowMessage had a duplicate list of `LVM_` messages. 
    * Rename the dups, update callsites to use the existing enum.
    * Add tests to confirm the correct behaviour
- Remove few redundant `else`s to reduce nesting

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Internal plumbing changes, should be not visible to consumers

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal, behaviour was verified with tests

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->

Issues.Title: WIP: [Accessibility][ScreenReader]: Fixing tooltip text announcing by NVDA/Narrator
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #2073
Original bug: [987952](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/987952)

## Proposed changes

- Add AnnounceText method to raise UIA notification (ScreenReader says notification text) when a tooltip is shown

<del>- Add IToolTip interface and implement it to unite elements (Control, ToolStripItem, DataGridViewElement) which can have a tooltip (this is necessary to the correct, simple and short implementation of raising UIA notification.)</del>

> ScreenReader reads the tooltip text of elements of in turn.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- A user can hear a text of a shown tooltip

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- No

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/66658882-11fce700-ec4b-11e9-95ab-769287de4313.png)

<!-- TODO -->

### After
- **A screen reader announces a text with a title of all tooltips (mouse and keyboard). 📗**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/66658891-16c19b00-ec4b-11e9-91aa-47ad841fb406.png)

![2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/66658939-2ccf5b80-ec4b-11e9-9cf2-8246ce386889.gif)

<!-- TODO -->


## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- Manual UI testing


## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

- Using NVDA and Narrator
<!--
     Microsoft prioritizes making our products accessible. 
     WinForms has a key role in allowing developers to create accessible apps. 
     
     When submitting a change which impacts UI in any way, including adding new UI or
     modifying existing controls the developer needs to run the Accessibility Insights
     tool (https://accessibilityinsights.io/) and verify that there are no changes or
     regressions. 
     
     The developer should run the Fast Pass over the impacted control(s) and provide
     a snapshot of the passing results along with before/after snapshots of the UI.
     More info: (https://accessibilityinsights.io/docs/en/web/getstarted/fastpass)
  -->


 

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

- .NET Core Version: 3.1.0-preview1.19458.7
- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.18362.356]

<!-- Mention language, UI scaling, or anything else that might be relevant -->
